Description: Lower body sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery globular aryballos; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of battling warriors; on left, part of foot of figure remaining, to right; on right, advanced right leg and genitalia of warrior to left, with lower part of his shield (its device a bird in flight to left; trace of tail, lower wing with added red band); incised splinter and spoked rosettes and blobs as filling ornament; below, three painted black concentric bands; whirligig pattern at bottom with added red on alternate blades.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
According to Amyx, the warrior pattern on this aryballos shows similarities with those painted by the Duel Painter.
Bibliographic references: Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (Catalogue no. 503B)
Amyx 1988 / Corinthian Vase-Painting of the Archaic Period (p. 96, no. B5)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 55, no. A14)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 217, no. 1) (below)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.125) (Phase 1)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
